text:
The DPRK has planned on a long protracted war with the US as given evidence to how well they're dug into their mountainous fortresses.  They've studied battles like Iwo Jima, Okinawa, and Iraq (remember that the Imperial Japanese used Korean forced labor to build island fortresses). 

If conflict turns toward the likes of Iraq, then the world can expect an insurgency to remain in North Korea. This insurgency will get their support from their traditional allies.

The best we could probably hope for is that the North Koreans develop a loose confederation of army general warlords that revolt against Kim Jong Un and force him into an enclosed Pyongyang (think of China's Ming Dynasty and their once Forbidden City).

Then an interim North Korean government could be established to negotiate a slow amalgamation of the North Korean generals to a unified political party that reunites with the South.  

We can expect China and possibly Russia to stymy this. The Japanese may be reluctant too, but not obstructive.  The South Koreans would also have to fight their own indifference toward a reunification.  

The reason for this is that Koreans aren't Germans, and this isn't the 1980s.  A reuinified Korea presents an economic threat to its neighbors.  Thus, the resistance and apprehension of its neighbors. 

Also, a sluggish reunification of a people so thoroughly exploited, brainwashed, and backwards will be an incredible burden on the South Koreans--much more so than what East Germans were on West Germans.  At least in Germany, there was the advantage of many centuries of a strong Christian culture to help heal the wounds upon reunification. And, the divisions Germany suffered weren't nearly as long as the Koreas'.

Likewise, when the reunification happens, we can expect Chinese and Russian interference to hurry up the equalization of benefits knowing that forcing "equality" (equal outcome over equal opportunity) will futher complicate Korea's domestic burdens, thus hindering a reuinified progress (think about how South Africa's hurried process that still hasn't hit a national stride).

However, when Korea is finally reuinified, it will be the economic and cultural powerhouse that could be somewhat compared to Germany. And, the reuinified Korea will remember it's friends as well as those who made them suffer--and who prolonged the suffering. I expect that when a reuinified Korea hits its national and natural stride, its influence will be such that both the Japanese and Chinese would even consider using the Korean alphabet to replace the way they write their languages.ï»¿

text:
Hm, don't know what's wrong with cars that are road legal in Germany where there is no speed limit on the autobahn and the death toll per 100.000 inhabitants is 4.7 in Germany (4.7 too many!) versus 11.4 in the US (WHO Global status report on road safety 2013, page 4).
Could that be interpreted as driving cars with suspensions and brakes that are only capable of 70mph are generally dangerous?
And by the way: most Europeans probably would raise an eyebrow, too, when as petite girl drives to the supermarket in her 3 ton SUV to buy a bag of groceries - maybe more of an eyebrow than you do when you see a small car with no windshield.ï»¿

text:
The Suzuki Jimny was originally known as the Sierra in Australia since the 1980s - used to come in hardtop and soft top - very popular as it used to be a great price.

These days due to safety itâ€™s not as popular as for $25-30k it isnâ€™t 5 star in crash tests and doesnâ€™t have all the features and mod cons of comparably prices hatches. (Such as cruise control)

To be fair though this car design is from 1998! So itâ€™s almost a 20 year old design- itâ€™s still a great vehicle but without optional features like cruise control, gps or climate control it can be uncomfortable on long drives full of speed cameras!

However it has always been the only car in class made in Japan, and he only real full time 4wd with locking diffs so if you live in places where it snows or ice is common itâ€™s perfect as itâ€™s cheap, small and very capable on the worst surfaces.

It would be on the top of my list if we had snow in Australia.

Ps these days itâ€™s call the â€œSuzuki Jimny Sierraâ€ due to people preferring the Sierra nameplate.ï»¿

author: Finn SÃ¸rensen

text: The NAS D-90 was the North American-legal Defender imported into the USA in 1994, 1995 and 1997. The reference here is to the few 1993 long wheel base 130s brought to the USA. There were also 87 imported into Canada only in 1994. I have one.  There were well over 6,000 imported into the USA during that window.  They were not brought in more recently because the company did not want to waste the number required for crash testing. And once the year of manufacture (YOM) is beyond 25 years, others from around the world can be imported. There are thousands Defenders in North America. There are many vehicles that can't be imported now if they do not meet crash testing standards. TVRs for example after the early 1990s.ï»¿

text: In complete fairness there are not any motor vehicles that are illegal to drive in the United States. At least on a federal level. Individual states have their own laws. The United States government does have a list of cars that cannot be sold in the United States by Automotive dealerships because of their emissions and safety standards. But Private Sales are perfectly legal and so is  driving them. At least as far as the federal government is concerned. But there are zero federal laws as it pertains to the operation of Motor Vehicles and if I go to another country and pick up any of these vehicles there is no federal law that stops me from driving them in the United Statesï»¿

author: Texarmageddon

text: Texarmageddon Hyper cars take certain qualities of high performance cars (supercars) to a new level, such as efficient propulsion, weight-efficient builds, and creating unique and outstanding aerodynamics. Although all these characteristics could qualify to make a great supercar, hypercars usually excel in all of them while being semi-fuel efficient and exceeding typical Autobahn speeds. Usually stocked with 10 or more cylinder engines, built from carbon fiber, with engines in the back for better aerodynamics, a hypercar focuses more on straight line speed,rather than handling performanceï»¿

author: Barsa

text: Not available for sale in the US, yes. Manufacturer not allowed to showcase the vehicle in the US at auto shows etc, yes on some. Several of these can be legally imported under the "Show and display" law. Others can be imported with restrictions saying you can't register them or drive them on public roads but you can still drive them on a closed track and private property. And all of them are legal to import once they are 25 years old. The only real reason why they are sudo banned in the US is because they didn't meet the emissions and safety standards required for a company to import them for sale. In the case of many of the low production number vehicles this could be just because the manufacture didn't want to sacrifice one of a handful made to be crash tested to be approved for the manufactures to import.ï»¿

author: n8dogg 5-7

text:
Ok, i will admit to one mistake, due to the fact that i could care less what version of the Skyline it is, but, yes, the R33, but only a very limited number and only certain years are allowed to be imported, but, the R34 will never be allowed in this country, according to one of the links a guy i deal with sent me. This is directly from the NHTSA, and pertains ONLY to the R33; To learn the modifications the petitioner started were needed to conform Nissan Skyline vehicles to the FMVSS, you should go to the Federal Docket Management System (FDMS) website at http://www.regulations.gov/ and access docket number ï¿½NHTSA-2005-22654ï¿½ by following the online instructions for accessing the dockets available at that web site. You should note that the petition sought import eligibility for 1990-1999 Nissan GTS and GTR "Skyline" passenger cars. After granting the petition, the agency learned that the modifications identified in the petition were not sufficient to conform certain model and model year vehicles that were covered by the petition. The agency therefore partially rescinded its grant of eligibility, leaving only R33 model Nissan GTS and GTR passenger cars manufactured between January 1, 1996 and June 30, 1998 eligible for importation.
Me personally, i have driven an R32 (i think that is what it was, it was a 1989), once for more than a few hundred feet, and was not impressed by it in the least. It is small, cramped, twitchy, and, to me, annoying to drive, but, i dont like any cars, whether they are small, medium or large. I will personally stick with my trucks and SUV's.ï»¿

text: biggman100 skylines are far from the fast legends they are known to be stock. But with $500-600 of modification can be 500hp street legal monsters. text:
TheShadowOwl - "The r34 is legal to import, there multiple ways to import a r34 legally"

No, there's only one way, and that's under the "Show & Display" rule, which limits the car to no more than 2500 miles of street driving per year.  If the paperwork is not kept up to day the car is seized by Homeland Security and crushed while the owner watches.

It will be 100% legal in a few years once the 25 year old date arrives.  Until then, then Show & Display method is the only way.ï»¿

author: Gopherchucks Games

text:
Anthony Marin
 its the grey market agreement , the front core support rules were used to get it passed, same as the type r civic's  , and Nissan didn't see any gain of interest here till the late 2000s. besides you can buy a Ferrari , lambo, viper , zo6 vette , Shelby super snake and so on,  all of them will destroy a stock skyline and a police cruiser.  plus the supra was sold here and they are almost the same in power and gearing. the cop thing is a myth.  the us just has a stupid 25 year rule due to lobbyist on the car manufactures part insuring the dealers get the first chance to sell to the native consumer. Canada is 15 years.  i live in Florida and have driven a r32 and a r33gt 25t. i know my state is lax on it but others states can get them too. not to mention my gsxr has never been caught by a cop NEVER!  yet i can get one made yesterday in japan. the whole thing is perpetrated by the assholes in government payed by the dealers union, to stop you from circumventing their bottom line.  im waiting for the r33 gtr to be properly legal here before import . and i will pay for storage for 6 months ahead of time in Yokohama, to beat the price hike as best i can.  the r32 is already way past its real value here. and most don't like the 33.ï»¿
author: Gopherchucks Games

text: because of its underground popularity we now have the gtr here in the states at every Nissan dealer you see lol and that thing kills its older brothers as well as the cops.  and most supertrash.ï»¿
